questions.text: Which of the following types of medical items requires sterilization?
questions.explanation: Needles are critical items that penetrate sterile tissues or the bloodstream and therefore require sterilization to prevent infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is suitable for use on tissues for microbial control to prevent infection?
questions.explanation: Antiseptics are antimicrobial chemicals safe for use on living skin or tissues. Disinfectants are typically used on inanimate objects, and sterilants aim to destroy all microbial life.

questions.text: Which biosafety level is appropriate for research with microbes or infectious agents that pose moderate risk to laboratory workers and the community, and are typically indigenous?
questions.explanation: BSL-2 is designated for work with agents that pose moderate risk and are indigenous. BSL-1 is for low-risk agents, BSL-3 for serious or lethal indigenous/exotic agents, and BSL-4 for dangerous/exotic agents with high risk of aerosol transmission and life-threatening disease.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a microbial control protocol that inhibits the growth of molds and yeast?
questions.explanation: Fungistatic agents inhibit the growth of fungi (molds and yeasts). Fungicidal agents kill fungi. Bacteriostatic inhibits bacteria, and bactericidal kills bacteria.

questions.text: The decimal reduction time refers to the amount of time it takes to which of the following?
questions.explanation: The decimal reduction time (DRT or D-value) is the time required to kill 90% (or reduce by one logarithm) of a microbial population under specific conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following methods brings about cell lysis due to cavitation induced by rapid localized pressure changes?
questions.explanation: Sonication uses high-frequency sound waves to create rapid pressure changes, leading to cavitation (formation and collapse of bubbles), which lyses cells.

questions.text: Which of the following terms is used to describe the time required to kill all of the microbes within a sample at a given temperature?
questions.explanation: Thermal death time (TDT) is the length of time needed to kill all microorganisms in a sample at a specific temperature. Thermal death point (TDP) is the lowest temperature at which all microbes are killed in a 10-minute exposure.

questions.text: Which of the following microbial control methods does not actually kill microbes or inhibit their growth but instead removes them physically from samples?
questions.explanation: Filtration physically removes microbes from liquids or air by passing the sample through a filter with pores too small for microbes to pass. Desiccation (drying) and lyophilization (freeze-drying) inhibit growth, and radiation kills microbes.

questions.text: Which of the following refers to a disinfecting chemical dissolved in alcohol?
questions.explanation: A tincture is a solution where the solvent is alcohol. For example, tincture of iodine is iodine dissolved in alcohol.

questions.text: Which of the following peroxygens is widely used as a household disinfectant, is inexpensive, and breaks down into water and oxygen gas?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen peroxide is a common, inexpensive household disinfectant that decomposes into water and oxygen, making it relatively safe for the environment after use.

questions.text: Which of the following chemical food preservatives is used in the wine industry but may cause asthmatic reactions in some individuals?
questions.explanation: Sulfites (e.g., sulfur dioxide) are used to prevent spoilage in winemaking and other food processing but can trigger asthma attacks in sensitive individuals.

questions.text: Bleach is an example of which group of chemicals used for disinfection?
questions.explanation: Bleach (sodium hypochlorite, NaOCl) is a halogen-containing disinfectant. Other halogens used for disinfection include iodine and chlorine.

questions.text: Which chemical disinfectant works by methylating enzymes and nucleic acids and is known for being toxic and carcinogenic?
questions.explanation: Formaldehyde is an alkylating agent that cross-links proteins and nucleic acids. It is effective but toxic and carcinogenic.

questions.text: Which type of test is used to determine whether disinfectant solutions actively used in a clinical setting are being used correctly?
questions.explanation: An in-use test determines if an actively used disinfectant solution in a clinical setting is microbially contaminated or if it is being used correctly, by testing its efficacy against a standard inoculum.

questions.text: The effectiveness of chemical disinfectants has historically been compared to that of which of the following?
questions.explanation: The phenol coefficient test was historically used to compare the effectiveness of other disinfectants to that of phenol.

questions.text: Which of the following refers to a germicide that can kill vegetative cells and certain enveloped viruses but not endospores?
questions.explanation: Low-level germicides kill vegetative cells and some enveloped viruses but are ineffective against endospores. Intermediate-level germicides are effective against vegetative cells, most viruses, and fungi, but not endospores. High-level germicides kill vegetative cells, fungi, viruses, and endospores with extended exposure, and sterilants kill all forms of microbial life.

questions.text: Sanitization leaves an object free of microbes.
questions.explanation: Sanitization reduces microbial load to safe public health levels but does not necessarily eliminate all microbes or sterilize the object.

questions.text: Ionizing radiation can penetrate surfaces, but nonionizing radiation cannot.
questions.explanation: Ionizing radiation (e.g., X-rays, gamma rays) has high energy and can penetrate surfaces and packaging. Nonionizing radiation (e.g., UV light) has lower energy and is primarily effective for surface disinfection as it does not penetrate well.

questions.text: Moist-heat sterilization protocols require the use of higher temperatures for longer periods of time than do dry-heat sterilization protocols do.
questions.explanation: Moist-heat sterilization (e.g., autoclaving) is generally more effective and requires lower temperatures and shorter exposure times than dry-heat sterilization because water helps to denature proteins more efficiently.

questions.text: Soaps are classified as disinfectants.
questions.explanation: Soaps are primarily detergents that work by mechanically removing microbes and dirt through emulsification. They have limited antimicrobial activity and are not classified as disinfectants, which are chemicals that kill or inhibit microbes on inanimate objects.

questions.text: Mercury-based compounds have fallen out of favor for use as preservatives and antiseptics.
questions.explanation: Due to their toxicity (e.g., neurotoxicity, nephrotoxicity) and environmental concerns, mercury-based compounds like merthiolate and mercurochrome are no longer widely used as preservatives or antiseptics in many regions.

questions.text: A medical item that comes into contact with intact skin and does not penetrate sterile tissues or come into contact with mucous membranes is called a(n) ________ item.
questions.explanation: Noncritical items (e.g., stethoscopes, blood pressure cuffs) only contact intact skin and require cleaning and low-level disinfection.

questions.text: The goal of ________ ________ protocols is to rid canned produce of Clostridium botulinum endospores.
questions.explanation: Commercial sterilization uses heat at a temperature low enough to preserve food quality but high enough to destroy common pathogens responsible for food poisoning, such as Clostridium botulinum endospores.

questions.text: In an autoclave, the application of pressure to ________ is increased to allow the steam to achieve temperatures above the boiling point of water.
questions.explanation: By increasing pressure, an autoclave prevents steam from escaping, allowing it to reach temperatures higher than 100°C (typically 121°C or 134°C), which is necessary for effective sterilization.

questions.text: Doorknobs and other surfaces in clinical settings are often coated with ________, ________, or ________ to prevent the transmission of microbes.
questions.explanation: Heavy metals like copper, nickel, zinc, and silver have antimicrobial properties (oligodynamic effect) and are sometimes incorporated into surfaces in clinical settings to help reduce microbial contamination.

questions.text: If a chemical disinfectant is more effective than phenol, then its phenol coefficient would be ________ than 1.0.
questions.explanation: The phenol coefficient compares a disinfectant's effectiveness to phenol. A coefficient greater than 1.0 indicates the disinfectant is more effective than phenol; less than 1.0 means it is less effective.

questions.text: If used for extended periods of time, ________ germicides may lead to sterility.
questions.explanation: High-level germicides can kill vegetative cells, fungi, viruses, and, with extended exposure times, endospores, thus achieving sterility. Sterilants are designed to achieve sterility.

questions.text: In the disk-diffusion assay, a large zone of inhibition around a disk to which a chemical disinfectant has been applied indicates ________ of the test microbe to the chemical disinfectant.
questions.explanation: A larger zone of inhibition means that the growth of the test microbe was inhibited over a wider area by the disinfectant, indicating greater susceptibility or sensitivity of the microbe to that chemical.

questions.text: What are some characteristics of microbes and infectious agents that would require handling in a BSL-3 laboratory?
questions.answer: Microbes requiring BSL-3 handling are typically indigenous or exotic agents that can cause serious or potentially lethal disease through respiratory transmission (inhalation route). Examples include Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Bacillus anthracis, West Nile virus, and SARS-CoV-1. These labs have specialized ventilation and safety equipment to prevent aerosol exposure.
questions.explanation: BSL-3 is for agents that pose a high risk of aerosol transmission and can cause serious or lethal disease, for which treatments may be available.

questions.text: What is the purpose of degerming? Does it completely eliminate microbes?
questions.answer: The purpose of degerming is to reduce the number of microbes on living tissue, typically skin, through gentle scrubbing and the use of mild chemicals (like soap or an antiseptic). Degerming does not completely eliminate microbes; it significantly lowers their numbers to reduce the risk of infection, for example, before an injection.
questions.explanation: Degerming aims to reduce microbial numbers on skin, often by mechanical removal and mild chemicals. It does not achieve sterilization.

questions.text: What are some factors that alter the effectiveness of a disinfectant?
questions.answer: Factors include: 1. Concentration of the disinfectant. 2. Contact time (duration of exposure). 3. Temperature. 4. Presence of organic matter (which can inactivate some disinfectants). 5. Type and number of microorganisms present (e.g., endospores are more resistant). 6. pH of the solution. 7. Nature of the surface being disinfected (e.g., porous vs. nonporous).
questions.explanation: Effectiveness depends on concentration, contact time, temperature, presence of organic matter, microbial load and type, pH, and surface characteristics.

questions.text: What is the advantage of HTST pasteurization compared with sterilization? What is an advantage of UHT treatment?
questions.answer: HTST (High-Temperature Short-Time) pasteurization reduces microbial numbers while preserving food quality (taste, texture, nutrients) better than sterilization, which can degrade these qualities. An advantage of UHT (Ultra-High Temperature) treatment is that it sterilizes the product (e.g., milk), allowing it to be stored for long periods at room temperature without refrigeration.
questions.explanation: HTST pasteurization preserves food quality better than sterilization by not overcooking. UHT treatment achieves sterility, giving products a long shelf life without refrigeration.

questions.text: How does the addition of salt or sugar help preserve food?
questions.answer: Adding high concentrations of salt or sugar creates a hypertonic environment. This draws water out of microbial cells by osmosis, causing plasmolysis and inhibiting their growth and metabolic activities, thus preserving the food.
questions.explanation: Salt and sugar create high osmotic pressure, drawing water out of microbial cells, which inhibits their growth and metabolism.

questions.text: Which is more effective at killing microbes: autoclaving or freezing? Explain.
questions.answer: Autoclaving is far more effective at killing microbes. Autoclaving uses high-pressure steam to achieve temperatures (typically 121°C) that denature microbial proteins and nucleic acids, leading to sterilization (killing all microbes, including endospores). Freezing, while it can kill some microbes, primarily inhibits microbial growth (bacteriostatic) by slowing metabolic processes and forming ice crystals that may damage cells, but it does not reliably sterilize.
questions.explanation: Autoclaving sterilizes by using high-temperature steam under pressure to kill all microbes, including endospores. Freezing is primarily bacteriostatic (inhibits growth) and does not reliably kill all microbes.

questions.text: Which solution of ethyl alcohol is more effective at inhibiting microbial growth: a 70% solution or a 100% solution? Why?
questions.answer: A 70% solution of ethyl alcohol is generally more effective. The presence of water (30%) in the 70% solution aids in the denaturation of microbial proteins and allows for better penetration into microbial cells. 100% alcohol tends to cause rapid surface protein coagulation, which can prevent further penetration and may not effectively kill the microbes within.
questions.explanation: A 70% alcohol solution is more effective because water is needed for the denaturation of proteins. Pure alcohol coagulates surface proteins too quickly, preventing deeper penetration.

questions.text: When might a gas treatment be used to control microbial growth instead of autoclaving? What are some examples?
questions.answer: Gas treatment (e.g., with ethylene oxide or formaldehyde) might be used for sterilizing heat-sensitive materials that cannot withstand the high temperatures of autoclaving. Examples include plastics (like Petri dishes, syringes), electronics, some medical devices, and packaged goods. These gases are alkylating agents that sterilize by denaturing proteins and nucleic acids.
questions.explanation: Gas sterilization is used for heat-sensitive items like plastics, electronics, and some medical equipment. Ethylene oxide and formaldehyde are examples of sterilizing gases.

questions.text: What is the advantage of using an iodophor rather than iodine or an iodine tincture?
questions.answer: An iodophor is a complex of iodine and an organic carrier molecule (e.g., povidone). Advantages include: 1. Slower release of iodine, making it less irritating to tissues. 2. Increased stability and solubility of iodine. 3. Reduced staining compared to iodine tinctures. 4. Prolonged antimicrobial activity.
questions.explanation: Iodophors (e.g., povidone-iodine) release iodine slowly, reducing skin irritation and staining while maintaining antimicrobial effectiveness and stability.

questions.text: Why were chemical disinfectants once commonly compared with phenol?
questions.answer: Phenol was one of the first effective chemical disinfectants used (by Joseph Lister in surgery). Its antimicrobial properties were well-recognized, making it a standard against which the effectiveness of new disinfectants could be measured using the phenol coefficient test. This provided a relative measure of potency.
questions.explanation: Phenol was an early, effective disinfectant, so it became the historical standard for comparing the efficacy of other chemical disinfectants via the phenol coefficient.

questions.text: Why is length of exposure to a chemical disinfectant important for its activity?
questions.answer: Chemical disinfectants require sufficient contact time to effectively kill or inactivate microorganisms. The killing process is not instantaneous; it involves chemical reactions with microbial components (e.g., proteins, cell membranes, nucleic acids). Shorter exposure times may only injure or inhibit microbes, while longer times allow for more complete inactivation or killing, especially for more resistant organisms or higher microbial loads.
questions.explanation: Disinfectants need adequate time to interact with and damage microbial cells (e.g., denature proteins, disrupt membranes). The killing process is time-dependent, especially for resistant microbes or high concentrations of microbes.

questions.text: When plotting microbial death curves, how might they look different for bactericidal versus bacteriostatic treatments?
questions.answer: A bactericidal treatment kills bacteria, so a microbial death curve would show a logarithmic decline in the number of viable cells over time. A bacteriostatic treatment inhibits bacterial growth but doesn't necessarily kill the cells. If the bacteriostatic agent is removed, growth may resume. Thus, a plot for a bacteriostatic agent would show the number of viable cells remaining relatively constant or ceasing to increase, but not decreasing significantly. If the agent were removed and cells plated on fresh media, growth would resume from the bacteriostatic-treated sample, unlike the bactericidal one.
questions.explanation: Bactericidal treatments show a decline in viable cell count. Bacteriostatic treatments show a plateau in viable cell count (growth inhibition); if the agent is removed, growth can resume.

questions.text: What are the benefits of cleaning something to a level of cleanliness beyond what is required? What are some possible disadvantages of doing so?
questions.answer: Benefits: May provide an extra margin of safety, further reducing the risk of infection or contamination, especially in highly sensitive environments or for immunocompromised individuals. Disadvantages: 1. Cost: Higher levels of cleanliness (e.g., sterilization vs. disinfection) are more expensive in terms of materials, energy, and time. 2. Damage: Harsh methods required for higher cleanliness levels can damage sensitive materials or equipment. 3. Environmental impact: Some strong disinfectants or sterilization methods can have negative environmental consequences. 4. Resistance: Overuse of certain antimicrobials could potentially contribute to the selection of resistant microbial strains. 5. Disruption of normal microbiota: Excessive cleanliness in everyday environments might reduce exposure to microbes necessary for developing a robust immune system (hygiene hypothesis).
questions.explanation: Benefits: Increased safety margin. Disadvantages: Higher cost, potential damage to items, environmental impact, potential for microbial resistance, and possible negative impact on immune system development (hygiene hypothesis).

questions.text: In 2001, endospores of Bacillus anthracis, the causative agent of anthrax, were sent to government officials and news agencies via the mail. In response, the US Postal Service began to irradiate mail with UV light. Was this an effective strategy? Why or why not?
questions.answer: This was likely not a fully effective strategy. While UV light is a germicide, it has poor penetrating power. It is effective for surface disinfection but would not reliably penetrate envelopes or packaging materials to kill endospores hidden within the mail. Bacillus anthracis endospores are also relatively resistant to UV radiation compared to vegetative cells. Ionizing radiation (like gamma rays or X-rays), which has better penetration, would have been a more effective (though more complex and costly) irradiation method for sterilizing mail contents.
questions.explanation: UV light has poor penetration power and would not effectively reach endospores inside envelopes or packages. Endospores are also relatively resistant to UV. Ionizing radiation would be more effective for this purpose.

questions.text: Looking at Figure 13.29 and reviewing the functional groups in Figure 7.6, which alkylating agent shown lacks an aldehyde group?
questions.answer: Assuming Figure 13.29 shows common alkylating agents like formaldehyde, glutaraldehyde, and ethylene oxide: Ethylene oxide lacks an aldehyde group. Formaldehyde (CH2O) has one aldehyde group. Glutaraldehyde (OHC-(CH2)3-CHO) has two aldehyde groups. Ethylene oxide is a cyclic ether (epoxide).
questions.explanation: Ethylene oxide is an epoxide (a cyclic ether) and does not contain an aldehyde (-CHO) functional group. Formaldehyde and glutaraldehyde do contain aldehyde groups.

questions.text: Do you think naturally produced antimicrobial products like nisin and natamycin should replace sorbic acid for food preservation? Why or why not?
questions.answer: Arguments for replacement: 1. Consumer preference: 'Natural' preservatives are often preferred by consumers over synthetic ones like sorbic acid. 2. Specificity: Some natural antimicrobials have specific targets, potentially being less disruptive to beneficial microbes. Arguments against complete replacement or for careful consideration: 1. Efficacy: Sorbic acid has a broad spectrum of activity and proven effectiveness. Nisin and natamycin might have narrower spectra or be less effective in certain food matrices or against certain spoilage organisms. 2. Cost: Natural antimicrobials can be more expensive to produce. 3. Stability and application: Their stability under various food processing conditions (pH, temperature) and ease of application might differ. 4. Regulatory approval and safety: While 'natural,' they still require rigorous safety assessment and regulatory approval for specific uses. A combination or case-by-case approach might be best.
questions.explanation: Natural antimicrobials like nisin (antibacterial) and natamycin (antifungal) could be preferred by consumers ('clean label'). However, considerations include their spectrum of activity, cost, stability, efficacy in different foods, and regulatory status compared to established preservatives like sorbic acid. They may be suitable for some applications but not all.

questions.text: Why is the use of skin disinfecting compounds required for surgical scrubbing and not for everyday handwashing?
questions.answer: Surgical scrubbing aims to achieve a significant reduction of both transient and resident microbiota on the hands of the surgical team to minimize the risk of introducing microbes into the surgical site, which is a sterile environment. This requires potent skin disinfecting compounds (antiseptics) with persistent activity. Everyday handwashing is primarily for hygiene, aiming to remove dirt and transient microbes acquired from the environment to prevent the spread of common infections. It typically uses soap and water, which mechanically removes microbes, and doesn't require the same level of microbial killing or persistence as surgical scrubbing.
questions.explanation: Surgical scrubbing requires a higher level of microbial reduction (including resident flora) and persistent antimicrobial activity to prevent surgical site infections. Everyday handwashing aims to remove transient microbes and dirt for general hygiene, using less potent agents.

questions.text: What are some advantages of use-dilution and in-use tests compared with the disk-diffusion assay?
questions.answer: Advantages of use-dilution and in-use tests over disk-diffusion: 1. Quantitative results: Use-dilution tests can determine the minimum effective concentration of a disinfectant (bactericidal or bacteriostatic). 2. Simulates practical conditions: These tests more closely mimic how disinfectants are actually used (e.g., on surfaces for use-dilution, or testing solutions currently in use for in-use tests). Disk-diffusion primarily shows if a substance has antimicrobial properties and relative zones of inhibition, but doesn't directly translate to efficacy in a specific application or dilution. 3. Evaluates liquid disinfectants: Use-dilution is specifically designed for liquid disinfectants applied to surfaces. 4. In-use test assesses real-world contamination: The in-use test directly checks if a disinfectant solution being used in a clinical or industrial setting is still effective or has become contaminated.
questions.explanation: Use-dilution and in-use tests provide more practical information about disinfectant efficacy under conditions closer to actual use, can determine effective concentrations, and assess contamination of working solutions. Disk-diffusion is more of a screening test for antimicrobial activity.
